projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by T. Mabb, For Iohn Pleyfere, at the White Bear, in the Upper-Walk of the New-Exchange; And Thomas Hors-man, next Door to the Signe of the Three Kings in the Strand, 1664.

div.head: THE Prologue.
div.l: LOvers to You I come, without a Bribe,
From one yâ€¢ boosts himself of your own Tribe,
And therefore hopes, that your good Natures may
On his behalf, above your Iudgements sway:
What you'le see here is naturall, all pretence
He disavowes, to Wit, or Eloquence:
With Friendship he presents you, and with love,
Such as are wont in his free breast to move,
Such possions as he feels, our Author writes,
And humours such, as he observes, indites:
From Conversation bringing to the Stage,
What he does think, will please the present Age.
And if you do not grudge your time here spent,
He will accept it for a Complement.

list.head: The Names of the Actors.
list.item: Pandora, a great Lady of the Prince his Family.
Lonzartes, Right Heire to the Principality.
Clearcus, a Lord of the Prince his Kindred.
Silvander, a Young Lord of the Court.

div.head: FIRST ACT.
div.stage: Enter Lonzartes and Clearchus in long Grey Cloakes over their Rich Cloaths, with Sanga and Geta, two Lacques carrying Lanthorns, the two Lords Enter a private House, the two Servants stay.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: COme Geta, our Lords have no more use of us, we may go sleep!

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: Tis a fair time indeed to sleep, when day begins to break? â€”this is a lew'd life, that our Lords do lead.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Why man? the Night was made for labourers to rest; and for great Lords to Revel in, come away.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p: My Lord, is not half so ill as thine.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
Geta.
sp.p: No, no, I will no more sully my credit, in thy company; I converse with our â€¢ all Dary-Maid, who a â€¢â€¢â€¢ rds me Honours, thou canst not guess at Sanga! Oh the great Fe â€¢â€¢ cities! that do belong to chast imbraces?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I like â€¢ mbraces well.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p:
I mea â€¢
â€¢ y Wed-lock man.

sp.speaker: San
sp.p: A Cox-comb thou art, and a Cuckold thou ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ be; a â€¢â€¢â€¢ w Fool.

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: A â€¢â€¢â€¢ w Rogue.

div.stage: A noyse within, Re-enter Clearcus, and Lonzartes, in the Dark.

sp.speaker: Clearcus.
sp.p: â€¢ otts on thy â€¢â€¢â€¢ ppery heeles; we are undone!

sp.speaker: Lonzartes.
sp.p: Let us draw, and stand upon guard, I hear some call within!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What was that strange noyse, you made?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: At the bot â€¢ om of the â€¢â€¢â€¢â€¢ rs, I fell, which gave the Al â€¢ rum to the doggs, and they wak'd all the Fami â€¢ y!

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Oh my Lord! what have you done? all the House are up, pray stand close a while,â€” are you alone?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Lonzartes.
sp.p: Thou art a very Villain Clearcus, thus to betray a poor Wench, that loves thee; and to force me accept a Favour, â€¢ a â€¢ hor to think on.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Be the blame mine, I have no joy in any thing, unless my Friend Participate;â€”if I have any skill in Woman; you will thank me for this favour, and say, you never had the like of Angelica.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Suppose she will not consent? must I ravish her?â€”you say she knows not of my coming

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I swear she does not.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Would I were out again, these Romances please not me;â€”pray how must I proceed?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thus, she is in Bed, the Room is dark, I'le entertain her with discourse, while you undress; then I'le retyre, and soon return with Light, to let her see my friend and I, must be as one man to her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I wonder all women do not hate thee, thou dost abuse all them that trust thee.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You are deceiv'd Lonzartes, such silly girles, do take it for a complement, to recommend them to a Noble Friend!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Well, I must now be subject to thy will, and do submit to do, what I detest!â€”me thinks this is a kind of Rape I undertake;â€”thou art too wild for my Converse Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Clear.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Hist, hist, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Give me your hand, softly, softly, follow me.

div.stage: Exeunt Woman leading them off, holding hands.
Enter the Old Prince of Syracusa, with Silvander, Aristonicus, Clothero, Ormuseus, and â€¢ rain.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: How does Lonzartes bear his Suppression Aristonicus? now he is full-man grown.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: Like a w â€¢ se man s â€¢ r, that will not seem to see, what he cannot remedy

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I have better thoughts for him, then he has for himself; if Clearcus spoyle him not!

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: When more years have overcome some evils, incident to youth, I hope he will be worthy your highest favours Sir.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Some of you should advise him to a little more sobriety, then Clearcus will allow of;â€”I app â€¢ ehend Silvander, that the Corinthian will quarrel, for my refusing to treat his Marriage with Theodosia, whom I design another way;â€” â€”she has a â€¢ ersion to him.

sp.speaker: Sil
sp.p: The Princes may be excus'd for her dislike, unto so sierce a man, the Corinthian Prince, is all fire, and fury, which does fright, not win â€¢ ffection.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: If Theodosia will be advised by me, I shall provide be â€¢ ter for her;â€”you know Lonzartes right Silvander! if he were reclaim'd, I would wish him to my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
I have some thoughts Sir, that Lonzartes does Consort with wild Clearcus, and complies in all his Vanities, onely to avoid your Jealousie, of
his higher thoughts of interest in the State! he is no fool Sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I wish it prove not too much his Nature, to be so debauch'd, for he has not higher thoughts of State interest, then I have for him; he has been wrong'd Silvander, and I will endeavour to do him right if he'l be worthy of it.

div.stage: Enter Lonzartes and Clearcus in a Garden.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, this grave face to me Lonzartes?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou are so wild, that I have lost my credit by conver â€¢â€¢ ng with thee, which I must redeem, by keeping â€¢ etter company hereafter.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Wisely resolved, and in good time declared; â€”I have indeed observ'd, that you of late converse with Ladies, and delight in rich lac'd Sattin, and in â€¢ ilver Petticoates; as if you meant to turn Apostate, from the freedom we have ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , and now seek your game in secret, my Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If I should, pray which is most Honourable? And most sutable to my Quality? The dayly terrour of getting such diseases, as â€¢ nhabit your dark houses, has frighted me into better purposes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Your Quality! I with your Prince sh â€¢ p had all the Ladies you desire, so I might have like freedom with their Maids.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall not spoyle your Market, but leave you those cheap â€¢ attel, at your own price.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
See the difference now, between your Pride, and my Humility; you have studied, learn'd discourses to such as must justifie your conversion (as you call it) but have never weighed the difference of our crimes;â€”such thoughts Lonzartes, do move, my tender Cons â€¢â€¢ ence, to take what â€¢
can find, for ready money; which I freely enjoy, without those frights you daily feel.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou dost mistake me, and exclaimest against crimes, I never understood.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: You can counterfeit I know, and may cozen all the World but me! I will not give my freedom up, to such follies as you serve, to be Master of all your wishes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall not labour to convert you, but will take leave to dispise your mean waies, while you envy mine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Envy! by Violin â€¢ s eyes, I do dispise you, and your wayes, and will wager any thing you dare, that I enjoy this night a beauty more exact, then any cloath-of-Gold-Dame you treat with, I en â€¢ y you! no, I pit â€¢ y you Lonzartes, that after such experience, at your years, you should be fool'd so;â€”confess now seriously, if you have ever met a better shape, a softer, or a whiter skin, or any more sweet, or more bewitching fair, and lovely, then my Ang â€¢ lica.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If I have not! what then?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why? she shall be Fine, and rich a â€¢ aid, when I so please! I can call her S â€¢ ltaness too! and by my fancy, raise her above those, the World allows of.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I do believe thee, and thy fancy, alike Extravagant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But why so serious on the suddain? and so dull? you shall have good Chear, and good Company to night, at the old place.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: I shall â€¢ et an ill Conscience by it!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
That sauce, agrees not with the Dainties
we must feed on, pray lay by your Conscience, untill morning.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
I wish I were well rid of thee, all thy Rhe
â€¢â€¢ rick, shall never ingage me, to meet such company again.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why pray, how can you spend your time better?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I do begin to hate my self, and will love thee no longer

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Very good;â€”Are not you the most debauch'd man in Syracusa? (except my self!) how come you by this Impudence? to blush for going to a merry meeting? Is not your own Lodging, beyond a Scandal? are not all the Wenches in that Street, your Pentione â€¢ s?â€” not love me! I will study to scorn you, and your love for ever; I dispise a man that does forsake his Principles.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I begin to hate thy over-much lewdness, and to see my own Deformities.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not love me!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Come, I do love thee, too well I love thee, shall we go home, and put off this meeting?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Lonzartes, though I do love your Friendship, I do hate this Humour in you, that thus would lay a blemish on me.

div.stage: Enter to them Lindamira and Tere â€¢â€¢ a, not at first seen.

sp.speaker: Ter
sp.p: See Lindamira, the two wild Princes are in our way, how shall we get by â€¢â€¢ m?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
Put on a confidence beyond theirs, and
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ will amaze them!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Can that be?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I'le be your Forlorne Hope, do but second me, and I'le secure your pass this time;â€”You'l see them start, shoot aside, as from a Baza â€¢ iske! the honest woman!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Barbarous!â€”I have heard indeed, they shun all virtuous women!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: They alwaies look over us, as if they saw us not; but where they have an interest, or hope to gain it, they can like subtil Serpents, humbly creep, to flatter and betray.

div.stage: He n â€¢ w sees the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A prize, a prize Lonzartes, each of us one; let us reconcile for this booty, and dispute at leasure;â€”you close walk invites;â€”which will you assault?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Neither, they are both virtuous?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Who knows that? have they done sucking?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Dost thou think there be none virtuous, beyond their infancy!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, much too many, but I hope better of these; give me the woman, and keep her virtue to your self:â€”I'le charge 'um both, there may be a Critical minute for me;â€”fair Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Hold my Lord, you are out at first, one of us is very brown I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You do not think your self so, or if you do, you think brown the best Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
I do indeed, think my beauty such, as may prejudice your Lordship, if you dwell on it; which gave me boldness, to interrupt your set Speech; least you engage past retreating;â€”our
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ is to find the Princess.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And ours, to entertain those, who have nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How would you entertain us my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: As young Gallants, use to treat fair Ladies; with love, and our best service.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I have no imployment for so great a Servant as your Lordship, and for love, I understand it not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That you may do is my ambition.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay, if you be come to ambition already! I guess your love will grow to such a Monster, in a moment, that I dread the thought on't.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You cut me off so short, you â€¢â€¢ nnot apprehend, what I would say.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Therefore I do it, because I do not care to hear.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What have I done Madam, to merrit this neglect from you?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: In the behalf of all our sex, I am the chosen Champion, against all men, who do believe, all Women do admire 'um.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When shall I have leave to speak? that I may inform you better.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: When I have done.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When will that be?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: When I am gone.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How can you be inform'd in absence?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: As much as I desire to know, I know already; â€”my good wishes shall attend your Lordship;â€”come Teretia; we may finde the Princess in the other walk â€¢ .

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now Sir, how do you like this Ladies mettle?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why well, I like her, and her humour very well.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You thought her a sure prize.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I did but hope so at the first, now I am sure of her, she is my own, if ever we do meet alone;â€” by this severity, she has cozen'd Teretia, and yo â€¢ , and confirm'd me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I must laugh, to think how thou art mistaken, in this innocent freedom virtuous women use, and would give a good summe, to see thee but conver â€¢ e a moneth or two, with persons of Honour, which I believe would reclaim thee, and fix those virtues, now â€¢ ost in a Chaos of wild actions.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
I marry, if you could shew me a woman, that would not be won; I would fancy ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
delight, to pass away an hour or two, at â€¢â€¢ de times, but all that I do meet with, are mine, before I wish it; so that I am alwayes forc'd to stand upon my guard amongst 'um.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thats no wonder, amongst those women you converse with;â€”shall I chuse you a mistris? and if you get her! let the reproach be mine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Shall she be worth my pains? if so! I will think on't, when I have time to throw away;â€” come will you go with me yet?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I'le stay here a while.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I'le go before then, and make ready for you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What pitty tis, such parts should be so drown'd!â€”
sp.l: Though I resolve to quit, I'me gui â€¢ ty still
If longer I do countenance his ill.

div.stage: Enter to him, as in the Garden, Theodocia, Pandora, Lindamira, Teretia, and Ladies, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Theodocia.
sp.p:
Lonzartes I have been laughing at Lindamiras relation of Clear â€¢ us humour; she ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
â€¢ he has abus'd him his own way, in the ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰
all honest women, whom he declares against.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
The encounter indeed was pleasant, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
the successe is beyond her guess! for the ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
â–ª that her neglects, have dash'd his hopes, by which he is grown confident, that her seeming scornes, were onely to dazle our eyes, while he doubts not to gain an interest.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I wish him joy my Lord, of his quick Victory, the next encounter, will decide this difference of Opinions.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But how dare you Lindamira, enter the lists of wit? with young Clearcus, who has the sharpest tongue in Syracusa.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: There is no contest so easie, his whole discourse to women, is ever of love, or something like it! and does believe that all our souls, delight in nothing else, which makes me interrupt him still as he begins, and never hear him out.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I â€¢ that civil, to a person, of his Quality?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Is he not angry, when you slight him so?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No Madam, I am his m â€¢ rth, and he is mine.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If Pandora would permit! I do fancy his conversion might be wrought by her, and his Eclips'd virtues, made to shine brighter then his vices do

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: 'Twill be a noble undertaking Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I wish he were with â€¢ n my cure.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: We'l joyne our forces Lindamira, for I shall easily consent unto so good a work, as may reclaim so great a person as Clearcus; a man so near alied unto the Duke!â€”but how must this Charitable work be done?

sp.speaker: Lon.
Pan.
sp.p: So, I be obliged no further then to civil visits, his birth does require that for him, which I deny to no man.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: How happy are you Cousin, that may dispose of your self as you please! I must speak, and look, and move, as my Father, and the State directs me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Great Princes â€¢â€¢ deed, are bound to some strict Rules, most Subjects understand not?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Highness complains without a cause, we hear the Duke will leave you to your own choise, only he will recommend.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: When Parents recommend, tis so like command, it frights me to think whom it may be.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Now you are safe from the Corinthian, have no fear untill you see occasion for it.

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I wish my dear Cousin, you would marry too, I should then like it be â€¢ ter I now dread to put on that yoak, by all the World so much desired?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Will my being in the pound, get your Highness out off it? why would you have me run the hazzard, to loose that happiness! now am sure of? by a single lifeâ–ªâ€”If men did ever appear in their own likeness! we might chuse someone, amongst many, worth the having, but in our sights, they are alwayes disguis'd in such shapes, and humours, as they believe we like best, and so cozen us, and themselve â€¢ too; for if they make us unhappy, it seldome failes, but we make them so.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No Oracle ever spoke truer; I am of your Sect Madam, (as to matters of Faith!) yet I would gladly have a Husband, though it be dangerous to put my heart into anothers keeping (And as my learn'd Author saves,) to give my freedom up, unto I know not whom! (nor ever can do, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ I have him)â€”this were a sadd condition Madamâ–ª if we had not the same Arts to cozen them, that think to cozen us.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Would! could get a merry heart, like yours Lindamira.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: I'le present your Highness with a piece of mine, I have enough for both.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Madam, The Prince calls for you;

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I attend him, pray Cousin go with me to my Father.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: A few such Excellent women would make this World a Paradice!â€”how have I walk'd in the dark, till now? how strangely been misled, by my affection to Clearcus? that have approv'd, and acted in all his ills; begun upon design, and led on, till custome has almost chang'd my nature, but will no more.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How now Lonzartes? walking alone? take heed the Devil find thee not at leasure.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: A greater then thy self can hardly find me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Very gravely replyed, if I mistake not, you are whimpering a â€¢ ter some great lady, and now practizing to play the fool wisely, to spend your time, adoring you know not who, nor why.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou are still ith' wrong.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Let us meet then, at the old place to night.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That's a freedom, I shall never take more, you have converted me, beyond all the Homilies I ever read, you have made me ashamed of my self for being so long like you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Oh Hypocrite! what new piece have you
got? that I must not be trusted with; come tell me, and I'le cry up your Austere purpose, and rail at your conversion, as if I did believe it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: VVhen you see me next in ill company, I am then that Hypocrite you mention.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Out upon these tender Consciences, they spoyle more mirth, then they are worth; let old folks hear Homilies, while we enjoy the time we have, and not whine away our youth, on dreams of virtue, which signifie we know not what.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Peace Clearcus, thou art not half so ill as thou appearest; but dost glory in talking worse, then thou canst be.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: VVhat should we talk of more then what we most delight in?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Of nothing less, because we often do delight in what we ought not own;â€”Is't not enough to offend the Gods through frailty, which perverse nature does invite us to; but we must provoke Heaven, beyond sence, and appetite, by our discourse, as if we studied to de â€¢â€¢ e those Powers, we ought to tremble at.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I hate Hypocrisie.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: And I abhor to aggravate my crimes, by such unnecess â€¢â€¢ y boastings, as thy wild brain delights in; when I offend I am sorry for it, dost thou all honesty dispise, all virtue slight?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
How Lonzartes, will you confine honesty, and virtue, to the fruition of one woman only? Fie, what a scandal is this to man-kind, as if there were no honesty, nor virtue but in such chast breasts as yours? what an affront to this good company, pray speak Gentlemen, is any here
of his opinion? can you Lonzartes shew me one young man, that looks as he were guilty? or any so old, who would be thought so weak?â€”Is this a fit design, to set up your Title to the Dukedom?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I see this is not the hour for your Conversion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor shall ever live to see that hour, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nor you I fear, ever live to tast, and relish the tr â€¢ e felicity obtain'd, by such a conquest on thy self; but I will pray for thee, and thy conversion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I had rather your Lordship were at Ierusalem, then see that day of my conversion; what have I done Lonzartes? to deserve such ill from you, do not provoke me to a revenge.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Revenge, for what?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Can you aske for what? suppose the gods should hear your prayers, and turn my heart, how miserable a man were I, how should I spend my time, for forty years to come; Is it not enough to forsake your cause, but you must seduce me too? Lonzartes, if you pray for me, I shall curse you heartily; I dare stay no longer with him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If this brave man this humour could expell, His virtues would his vices far excell.

I have put on this Cloak of wantonness onely to avoid being thought a serious man, least the Duke grow jealous of my pretentions to his Crown;â€”while the Duke is civil and I am safe;â€”he shall be so too?â€”But if I finde
designes against me; I have Friends, and force enough, to gain my right by this;â€”Oh but Theodocia does unman me quite;â€”when I look on her, all these high thoughts do vanish, and I become the humblest creature in the Court:â€”
sp.l: I have no Title, that I ere shall owne,
Vnless she daine to raise me to the Throne.

div.head: THE SECOND ACT.
div.stage: Enter Lonzartes alone, Clearcus hearkning at the Door.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: OH Cloris, Cloris! what stange unwonted pains I feel? what fears? what new disease conceales my blood?â€”if it be love, twill not offend the gods, because my soul does now rejoyce to find, Beauty and Virtue so divine, that both may be well worshipp'd at one Shrine.

div.stage: Clearcus chaps him hard on the Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Are you talking in your sleep Lonzartes? or is it some divine meditation, thus transports you?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You are too rude Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Sir, you can be angry then I see; I thought your conversion, had set you above such passions, as we wicked men are subject too.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I do confess thou didst make me start, and speak hastily, but I am not angry, nor can be with thee.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I'le try your temper presently,â€”Oh! Beauty and Virtue so Divine, both may be worshipped in one shrine; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What of this, you heard me repeat an old Song.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: An old Song to a new Tune Lonzartes: dost thou pray for my Conversion this way? must I get a Cloris to sigh after?â€”as thou dost;â€” I have heard all, and have observ'd thee too, I and do guess who Cloris is,â€”come, tell me quickly, that way to oblige me to silence; for if by my own skill, I do discover her, I'le lay thee open to the World, tell me who Cloris is, least I tell thee; Adiew.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How can he discovee that I love, when I know it not yet my self?â€”Yet I may admire her, and by my adoration of her virtuesâ€”
sp.l: Be by them, from all meaner passions freed,
When this new virtue, shall my vice exceed.

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: What the Devil ailes my Lord? his wonted mirth is changed into hey â€¢ oes, and twenty times a day, he sends me on sleeveless Errants, that he may be alone; I think Lord Clearcus will prove the wisest man at last;â€”I have been five times this morning to enquire, if the Princess be in health! if she be stirring, or if near ready! if she go to the Temple!â€”And after dinner I must enquire, if she have dyned! if she comes forth in publick! if she ride abroad; and thus twenty times a day, he tires me, with the â€¢ e silly Errants, when I might aske them all at once, and save much labour; I'le try if I can find some way to contract these Embassies;â€”tis well for my Lord, that his man is wiser then himself.

div.stage: Enter Silvander with Lindamira, and her Maid.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Do not my looks Lindamira enough express what I would say?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Yes, to me, who do discern your passion thus suppressed, more clear, then by those loud noyse â€¢ , which some Lovers most delight in.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
But how shall I be assured, this is not
â€¢ aliery?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Cannot you judge by my looks, as well as I by yours? what kind of security do you require? I have no Citizens that will be bound for my good behaviour!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: A serious word or two, with a kind look confirm'd, will secure me against the World.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Will this look serve? and I am yours, suffice for words? with this hand given from my heart! ingage beyond your wish.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: It does, may I beâ€”

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay, no strange lines I beseech y â€¢ u, make me not jealous by professing more then I expect.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I am confirmed.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I shall try your temper, if my merry humour hold!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: 'Tis that free Innocence, I most adore.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And that I can afford enough off, at an ea â€¢â€¢ e rate.

div.stage: Enter Clearcus to them, Silvander goes off.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Lordship was going another way, pray let not me divert you, my lodging is far off.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Madam, I have long sought an opportunity to kiss your hands there.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You may do it here, and save the labour of going so far for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Do you call that honour nothing, which I do prize above the World? and would give all my interest on Earth, to purchase one kiss of your fair hand, by a free consent.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: The World is little beholding to your Lordship, for so low a value, that will give all your interest on Earth, for a kiss of my hand, and this I must in civility, look, as if I did believe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I'le swear it Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Thats as easily done, as said, but I am hard of Faith.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How shall I obtain more credit?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I'le shew you a short way; bring me a conveyance of half your Land, and you shall have two kisses of my hand, three if you please; and as you like your Market, you may have more, for the other half of your Estate! and this is much cheaper then to give all the World for such an honour.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Why do you mock me? who truly love, and honour you above all women! by those ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
eyes I do.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
How can I believe it? when I know you ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
thus to every woman that you meet.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: May my hopes nere prosper, if you are not the only object of my heart.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No touching good my Lord, my Affairs calls me away, I must be gone.

div.stage: He proffers to kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And I must wait on you home Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: â€¢ le rather stay here this Twelve-month, then give your Lordship that trouble.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Am I such a Monster, in the opinion of all Women, as you make me?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I must take care you make not me one;â€” Oh happy deliverance!

div.stage: Enter to them, Theodocia, and Pandora, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This is such a piece of nic â€¢â€¢ y, as I nere met before;â€”these are no company for me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Stay (learcus, I would speak with you;â€” my Cousin Pandora tells me, you Court Lindamira, which her self does not much deny.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am pract â€¢ zing I must confess, how to talk to Ladies, and have learnt some Speeches to that purpose, whereof Lindamira has had her share.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You have mocked her then! and intend her onely for your ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ !

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Methinks his silence, and that legg, shewes more love to me, then I know what to do with.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Excellent Girle! how she playes with his wanton humour!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, if Lonzartes fall on me too? I shall be over-whelmed with wisdome.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now there is some hope of him, his look is Civillized already.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Are you not pleased Clearcus? to see the whole Court concerned for you? to see your self so valued, methinks it should stir up the Noble Blood of your great Ancestors, to set you on to such actions, as may out-shine their stories, and not loose one day more, in your wild waies.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Madam, Your Language, and your Looks, agree with your great soul; I can be proud to be so taught, when the Princess Theodocia, and you direct, twere great stupidity to shew neglect;â€” but in my Opinion Madam, one of a Family is enough to be a Saint;â€” â€¢ twould take from great Lonzartes credit, and render his conversion no rarity; if I should become virtuous too.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Pandora, and I, are much obliged to you, for your good opinion of us, I wish all our Sex were so too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My opinion and my practise, differ very much Madam; I do honour virtue in your Sex, as much as any man; but my Tallent lies the other way, Lonzartes does enough Illustrate the Platonnick Name, and Eminently maintain, that high Serassick flame, which is above my reach.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Tell me now Clearcus, is there not more
relish in this Conversation? then with your Getinas, and your Angelinas!â€”that blush shewes well, there is some hopes of grace in that blush

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hold your pratling, my conversion does not belong to you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I hope I may direct you to a Lady, that will work that wonder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hold your peace then, till we be alone.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: We'l be gone Pandora, and not hinder so good a work;â€”you shall neither of you go with us,â€”but if you please Clearcus, Lindamira may walk with you a little longer.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No Madam, I have enough of her already, she out-wits me; we shall nere agree.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I have got credit enough for a young Souldier, by my honourable Retreat, from so hot a charge.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: Let us now persue our Argument, for thy Conversion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
It comes on a pace;â€”what a fine Gentleman are you grown, since the Spirit of Chastity has possest you? and I must live chast, that I may have the Honour, and Felicity to be in love!â€”to be a fool! to intangle my self in
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ that I shall nere get out of! I'le none of it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Let my old Friend-ship so far prevail, that on my request you will sometimes converse with Pandora, if thy visits do ingage her to undertake thy cure! and she do work that Miracle! she
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
â€¢â€¢ lue what her self has made worthy of her
self; for so wilt thou be, if thy wandring fancy, were once fixt?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: So then all this bussle, is to make me in love; though you know, I have been a thousand times in love already.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I Clearcus, I know thy thousands, but I would have the â€¢ once in love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I never will be mad, as you are; yet to give you, and the World satisfaction in this point; I will condemn my self to one Months pennance, and make experiment to look, and talk as idlely with Pandora, as you do with your Divinest Cloris! â€”If I were sure Pandora were not to be won; I could fancy a pretty kind of pastime, by raising my desires to hopes of what I cannot have! but I could never meet a woman yet, that was impregnable; and my nature is not capable of being converted, by any that I can conquer;â€”Pray Sup at my Chamber this night.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I will not fayle, if you will go with me unto Pandora?â€”
sp.l: And visit her, while this good motion's warm,
'Gainst all your feares, I'le fit you with a charm.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I go.

div.stage: Enter Pandora with Lindamira and Ladies in her Chamber, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Lindamira you must be my second, they will be two, to one else.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Gladly Madam, I cannot wish a gentler Enemy, then him that thinks he has me at his mercy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But if you be over-sharp upon him, you may hinder the great work, we undertake! and make him hate all honest Women for our sakes.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I shall use him with more Art, and lead him on with hopes, that all our Sex do scramble for him;â€”if I can fit his Fancy, and his Wit, T'le ingage him in a concern for you, and then mannage my young Gallant to my will, till I confute his common places, so often urged to the prejudice of Ladies, I cannot fancy better sport, then to see him mad in love with you Madam.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: The gods forbid, I would not cure him at that rate, for my own sake, and his; least that prove a greater evil, then he now has; I shall be very careful, to give him no incouragement, for thoughts of that nature, my undertaking is not beyond a common civillity, as to all others of his Rank.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That will do it, if I mistake not;â€”and catch you both I hope,â€”here he comes?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Madam, I have brought my Friend to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thus far Madam, in order to my ingagement, I have given you the trouble of the first visit, I ever made against my will.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Your Lordship, does me honour; came you now from Court?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and left the Princess Theodocia in great complements with her kind Father, who has now declared against the proud Corinthian, and given Theodocia her free choice where she please.

sp.speaker: Pan.
Lon.
sp.p: The Duke and she, are not yet parted Madam;â€”how now Lindamira, are you tonguetyed? no welcome for my Friend, to encourage him to like of civil company;â€”You look as if you feared to loose your Gallant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, no, she knows she has too fast hold of my heart, to part so easily.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: â€¢ Tis Honour enough for me, to be in the number of your Martyrs Sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: How long have you two been acquainted?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Ever since last night Madam.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And dost thou sigh already?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: 'Tis onely to give you warning, by my harmes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I thank your care, but I am arm'd against the World.

sp.speaker: Cle.
Lon.
sp.p: You may, you may.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: Madam, You speak, as if you held mankind at a defiance.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: By way of Marriage, I do, but I can value all men that I see worthy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He must be a bold man, who does designe beyond the favours you a â€¢ low, but have you made vowes against marriage Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No vowes, but such resolves, as are unchangable.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You are severe to men.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If all Women were of your opinion Madam? how should the World be Peopled?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I marry Madam, that was well urg'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I thought Lindamira you would have been on my side.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: So I am, when you are in the right, this is our common cause; Suppose you bring these two Lords, and they bring twenty more, to be of your judgement, and this Heresie should spread; what will become of us, who think of nothing else but Marriage?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: She tells you true Madam, when her own concern is at stake, you may excuse her.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do, and will make good my argument alone.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Never to Marry Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Never my Lord, is my full resolve.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You are the happiest, and the wisest Lady living! and I the joyfullest man, if you'l permit me to adore you at this distance, for I am of your own opinion Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Two Fannaticks well met.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: So long as your respects be free from love, my house is open to you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You are all witnesses, that this Lady does adopt me her avow'd Gallant, on the conditions before mentioned:â€”you give me leave Madam to talk of love, and to carry up this jest, as high, as he who really does love.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: I do, so it be ever in Publick; all private visits, and all whisperings are excepted.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis enough Madam;â€”This is a pretty kind of Entertainment, I never thought of: Lonzartes thou art in the right, this will be sport beyond my hope.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: But how does Lindamira like, to see her new Gallant, thus taken from her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis her â€¢ wn fault, she might have fix'd me another way, if she had been wife.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Indeed Lindamira, I thought not of your concern, and did conclude too rashly, but I will use my interest on your behalf.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: 'Twill not be needfull Madam, I know all his professions to you, are meant to me.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: Very prettily contrived,â€”This is a new kind of witâ–ª I never heard of; so then you are to love me, in spite of your teeth, and I you, in spite of mine; what will this come to at last?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Mirth man, all the year a constant mirth:â€”Is not this better then spending your time in a smoaky house, with your old Acquaintance?

div.stage: Silvander, and Lindam â€¢ ra do converse while the others talk.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I cannot tell you that, till I have tryed this, as long as I have the other.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, do not perswade your Friend, all this earnest is a jest, I allow you as much mirth as you please, so the conclusion be serious.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: We leave the success unto the Fates;â€” Clearcus may in time have pitty on you Lindamira, he does not yet believe, you are in earnest.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor ever shall do Madam, till I see her heart break, and then 'twill be too late.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: He dissembles well, for so young a Schollar Madam.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: We have done all well me thinks, and now tis time that we retire.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: How soon may I make my next visit to you Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: As often as you please my Lord, at publique hours.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How did I perform my part Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You fell too soon into your humour, he sees you mock him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That's all I ayme at, he has too much wit to be abused; my onely business is to let him see, that he cannot cozen me;â€”I believe you will see this Scene changed, at his next visit, if I have any skill, you will be troubled with him.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: I am arm'd at all points, against all men, and him most.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Oh Cousin! I am freed from all my fears, and come to rejoyce with you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have rejoyced already Madam, and have begun a Scene of mirth, will hold us long;â€” Had your Highness come a little sooner, you had sound the late Convert Lonzartes, and his Friend Clearcus here, who is become my a vowed Gallant, and looks as if he liked our company already.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Then you have hopes to cure him;â€” Pray order it so, as I may come to your next meeting, my heart is now so light, that I could play with any thing;â€”Can I have no part in your Comedy?

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: For two reasons, your Highness can onely be a looker on â€¢ tis petty Treason to make love to you, though in jest; and then your beauty is too dangerous to be dallied with; these be edge-tools, too sharp for us to play with.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why may not Princes participate in such innocent mirth? we make stricter Rules then need; true virtue will shine through such thin clouds without a prejudice, and be above the reach of vile tongues.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I Madam, if you could shew a rule, to distinguish between Innocence and Guilt;â€”But we often see that Angelical virtues are aspersed, by malicious tongues, and no quality exempt, from rude censures.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I differ in opinion, Princes may enjoy harmless mirth, as freely as we; to be too much reserved, does look like disguise.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I would be so merry Lindamira. as should defie all scandall, and with an open face justifie it to the world; to wear alwayes a stiff-state face, is intollerable.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p:
Private persons may be bold that way, when few eyes observe,â€”But Princes are ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
on Pirameds, for all to see, an â€¢ immitate.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
You shall not fright me from your mirth, with this grave lecture, are they not, both my near Relations, whom you endeavour to reclaim â€¢
why may not I share in so worthy a designe?â€” I fear Lindamira she doubts least I may gain her Gallant from her.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: She may well be jealous, if your Highness undertake him, I shall have small hopes, if you two quarrel for him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: VVhy Lindamira? is Silvander vanished?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No Madam, the more Trophies I can fairly get by Victories on others, will raise his Conquest higher, who gaines me from the rest.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Thou art safe, and m â€¢ yest say any thing, Silvander is thy security against all scandal, though you carry it thus unconcern'd, the secret spread.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: 'Tis time it should do so, now we do own
Our love, tis fit the secret should be known.
Your Highness may assist, while you look on,
Though onely we, the active part do own.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Let us retire to council then.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: What is thy business honest Geta? How does Lonzartes thy brave Lord?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: My Lord is in good health of body Madam, his brains are only out of order.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: How meanest thou Geta, has he got a blow on his head?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: Only some fumes from his heart Madam, makes his head addle, tis call'd the Spleen of late, and much in fashion; his Lordship does desire to know the Princess mind this morning, what she meanes to do all day?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: This will be a hard question to the Princess fasting, why would he know all this now?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: Because he has some great affairs for me to mannage, and cannot spare me to ask, so often as I use to do

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Of what nature, be thy particular queries Geta?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p:
He would know how she slept last night? in what health now? by what hour she will be drest? when to her devotions? and then, where she walks this morning? and if she dine in publique? then how she intends to pass her time till night? else I must come twenty times, for
what you may at once dispatch me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: And does Lonzartes send thee, to enquire all this at on â€¢ e?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: These women are so silly, they Aside. cannot reach a deep design;â€”No but he does every day make me trou â€¢ le my self, and every body that I meet, to ask these questions severally, which I would do at once, to shew him I am a man of quick dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Oh! is that the matter? I can fit thee with one answer to all these;â€”Tell thy Lord, the Princess did take cold last night, and will keep her bed all day.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p: I like it well, and wish her Highness would do so this moneth.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Out Traytor, I'le make thy Lord braine thee for that wish.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p: Why Madam? I meant no harm, 'twas but to save you the trouble, and me the same questions to morrow, and so on till Dooms-day, I think.

sp.speaker: Ter
sp.p: Well Sirra, for this time, 'le not complain of you, this Jest shall excu â€¢ e your knavery.

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: This wil â€¢ be a play day for me, I like this lying a Bed well.

div.head: THE THIRD ACT.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: TEll me then who Cloris is?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I dare not trust thee yet.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will know now, or break all Friendship with you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I swear I must not yet.

div.stage: Enter to them Theodocia, Pandora, L â€¢ ndamira, Te â€¢ etia, and Ladies, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Then look to your self, least I discover Cloris.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Where did you leave my Father Lonzartes?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I have not seen the Prince to day Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I was told, that you were walking with him just now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That may well be Madam, for his braines do crow of late;â€”do ye see how he stands;â€” Lonzartes the Princess speaks to ye.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: To me, does your Highness command me anything?

div.stage: Silvander, and Lindamira entertain themselves in whisper.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Did not I tell you Madam, that his brains are turn'd he neither hears, nor sees of late;â€” The Idea of his Seraffique love, takes him wholly up, from all converse with us mortals.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Hold your prateing, or I shall be angry.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What has made you so grave of late Lonzartes? all your wonted mirth is gone.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: No man is alwaies in good humour Madam.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He's in love Madam, on my knowledge, o're head and eares in love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: In love, Lonzartes, I thought you had not been at leasure, to be in love;â€”Tis your fault Clearcus, that have not councell'd your Friend better.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Thus am â€¢ chid for your follie; who reject all my councels, and refuse all my approv' â€¢
Antidotes, which do preserve me against that Serpent (you call love) while he convers'd with me, he was safe Madam.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Thou hast fool'd enough Clearcus, the Princess and al â€¢ the company are weary of it:â€” If your Highness allow him this freedom, he wil â€¢
grow troublesome.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Is it Love Lonzartes? or is Clearcus onely merry with you?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Your Highnessâ–ª knows him too well, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
credit all he sayes this way, he is at thi â€¢ time, very angry that I have chid him for his lewd life, an â€¢
have with-drawn my self from his ill companyâ–ª which he imputes to my being in love.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p:
I say he is in love, most seriously in love â€¢
shall I unmask this grave Reformado, and ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
you the Lady now?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: If Lonzartes be content, I would gladly see her, whom he thinks worthy of his heart.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No matter for his consent Madam so you like it.â€”And thus I begin my tryal;â€”By your good leave Ladyâ€” Tis not here;â€”nor is it this;â€”nor is it you Lady?

div.stage: He holds them a'd to Lonzartes, one by one.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I lament the losse of such an honour.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou art become a pretty fool Clearcus, dost thou not observe how all the Court do laugh at thee?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Yes, and shall make them laugh at you,
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ have done; if Pandora will make the next tryall.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: I am content to try, what this will come to.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Now Sir, have at you;â€”Tis not your good fortune neither Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: How can you make Lonzartes an amends, for all this abuse.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will give him present satisfaction, if your H â€¢ ghness will permit me to bring him to you?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: To me! think you Lonzartes is in love with me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Tis a Cloris in the clouds, one much above his reach, which you onely are Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: With all my heart, I sh â€¢ ll be proud to own his conversion, as a Trophie of my honour.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: See if his guide do not make him avoid the tryal;â€”stop him there;â€”Lonzartes the Princess calls you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I'll cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
He threatens me,â€”guilty I'le ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ ;â€” now Madam, do you see no ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ in his
face?â€”no change yet?â€” speak all,â€”you are all assistants in this Judgement.

div.stage: Lonzartes throws him off in anger.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: It will disturb a Saint, to be thus subject to the fancies of a fool.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Be not disturb'd Lonzartes, you take this in earnest, which we look on as a jest, only to pass the time; Clearcus has more wit, then to be in earnest.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
I hope your Highness will not prefer his follies, before my professions, who disclaim such ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
presumption.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: If you turn this jest to earnest Lonzartes, I shall believe Clearcus;â€”I take it now as R â€¢ llier â€¢ ; â€”I wonder Lindamira you get not hold of some young lovers heart?

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: I have twenty in store Madam, more then I know what to do w â€¢ th.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Then you allow as many lovers, as you can get, and mean to chuse the best.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p:
I think tis credit for women to be admir'd and honour'd by worthy men; it shews a value, to move so many to a general Esteem, and must
â€¢ e the womans ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ if she deserve a censure.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
You are in the right Lindamira, men may designe, â€¢ ut wo â€¢ en may destroy, faster then they
â€¢ an ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ ; my thanks unto Clearcus for our mirth.

sp.speaker: â€¢ le.
sp.p: Mirth ought to be our business Madam.â€”
sp.l: The an â€¢ ry gods aff â€¢ rds cross Fates to give
Vs ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ enough, and troubles while we live.

div.stage:
â€¢ xeunt Lonzartes and Clearcus
â€¢ everally.
Enter the Prince and Lords, who meet the Ladies going off.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: We were now discoursing of your Gallant Pandora, have you hopes to work this miracle?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: This Lady and I, have ventred our credits on this conversion Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: To recl â€¢ im him, were a good work; but suppose he fall in l â€¢ ve with either of you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: At his pe â€¢ il that, let Lindamira look to her self, I am safe.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I have a sure retreat Sir, tis but see â€¢ ing to comply, and ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ give ore; for he can love none that he can conquer, and I am resolv'd rather to be vanquish'd, then not to be rid of him when I see my time.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Could all her Beauty with my love expire
Her flowing Wit, would s â€¢ ill create new fire

div.stage: Enter to them Clearcus and Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You two I know, come now from exercizing of your â€¢ roopes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No Sir, we went hence just now; I wish my Troop hereto guard me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Have you an Enemy in view Clearcus?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
I have many Sir, that have â€¢ ob'd m â€¢ of
my peace; I cannot sleep of late, but have a thousand fancies, which do set my brains on fire.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Take heed it prove not love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That is the danger Sir, for if Pandora do keep her resolve for single life; I may be in love; for I do feel strange alterations that I know not what to make of.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Have you no affection left for me my Lord? can you so soon forget your last nights professions?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Now Sir, you see how I am assaulted, I shall be pull'd in pieces presently.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Si'vander and I, will secure you from Lindamira.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: If I were assured you could Sir, I should like her wit, and humour well,â€”but I fear,â€” if I should be in earnest, she would be so too.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You see his inclination is for me Madam, so that what ever he shall say to you hereafter, is meant to me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor so, nor so, sweet Lady, I do respect Pandora, above all her Sex; you throw out hoocks to catch young Gallants, the neglects those are laid for her, thats my danger.

sp.speaker: Princ â€¢
sp.p:
What riddle is this
â€¢ learcus? dost thou desire, that thy desires may not be answered?

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p:
Yes Sir, from some persons, for if my love
â€¢ e return'd, all ends in the fruition, (as most
â€¢â€¢ amples shew,) But if Pandora keep her resolve for single life, then I can raise my fancy while I liveâ–ª to â€¢ doration of her beauty, and that virtue, with a continual delight, which will last while I last.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
You are then my Lord, the happiest lover
living, for you will find my Cousin, just as you wish.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pray Madam, answer not too fast for me, for if I find Clearcus a person of such Noble Nature, beyond what I did ever hope to meet in man; I may change my Opinion of men for his sake; and therefore 'tis best to find some other sport, least we destroy each other.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Look you now? I am Treypand.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Start not Clearcus, she but mocks you, you are both ingaged for this month to Entertain us, and your selves, no going off now.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I shall not break Covenants.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor I Madam, though I do sometimes reminde you of your resolve against Marriage, whereon depends my bliss, secure me but of that, and I am ever yours.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: I shall endeavour what I can, to give you that satisfaction

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I kiss your fair hand on that word, which has given new life to my doubtfull heart, and now I do de â€¢ ie Lonzartes gravity, to put his heart in a more loving dress, then mine shall be hereafter.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: If Lonzartes can love too, my wonder ceases.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: He is my servant Sir, and has a chief part in the Comedy.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I like your pastime well, but me thinks Lonzartes looks as if he were compell'd unto his part, and will do it s â€¢ urvily.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That's the sport Sir, and will afford the more variety.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall be glad Sir, if I might be excus'd.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: By no means Servant, what an affornt is this, that I must beg your favour, in the face of the whole Court to own me?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You must not be so grave Lonzartes, all is for our mirth.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Now Sir, have not I done your work for you?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Would thou wert hang'd, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Give me better words, or I'le talk aloud.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Was ever man thus hamper'd, between jest and earnest?

sp.speaker: Lin.
Prince.
sp.p: When begins the love Clearcus? this is only talking of it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: It is begun already Sir; if I had not valued this Excellent Lady above the World; I had not â€¢ aine this care to secure my interest to a perpetuity.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Madam, you are not to believe a word of this, for he has with the same grave face, sworn the same to me but Yesterday.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That was in jest Madam, but now every action of my life, shall justifie each syllable I utter unto you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I shall endeavour to believe it my Lord, and yet allow you the same Christian liberty with Lindamira, and the rest, as you had before.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Madam, you speak, as though you did not
value my respects, now my whole soul is set to serve, and honour you alone.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I must confess, I cannot change my faith, so fast as you do your discourse;â€”And then as I remember my lesson, is to keep my distance, least I loose my lover.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: True Madam, as to comply, but you are to see, and credit my ambitious love, and to admit it with the same Esteem, I serve you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: How can I do that, and not return you love for love? and then you will dispise me; pray my Lord, at your next visit, bring my part in writing, that I may not erre in it.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: She is in the right Clearcus, you now seem to seek such contradictions, as all the Court will laugh at; consult with Lonzartes against your next visit.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If he will follow my advise, he may do well Sir;â€”now we are alone, tell me what crotchets next? prethee make me understand what thou wouldest have Pandora do?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I think you were best release me the residue of my mon â€¢ h, that I may go se â€¢ k my wits, where I last left them;â€”must I see none of my old Friends, untill this month be over?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If you consider your promise, not see one of them.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Then shall I be lost, if those preservatives be all forbid me; I do find already love will be Predominant.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: The better for you if it be;â€”let us now talk seriously;â€”suppose Pandora may be won, can you fancy a happiness on Earth, beyond having her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, I do fancy that having twenty, is better then any one in â€¢ hristendom.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou dost not love then, else, that one belov'd, has more variety then a thousand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Make but that good, I'le marry her to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You think then she is already at your dispose.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When she once sees that I am in earnest, she will be, what I will have her; and the truth is Lonzartes, I do like her best of all I ever talk'd with, and have great fear that I shall be like other men, who never value what they have, which makes me cover what I cannot get.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Suppose some other do obtain her, while you are thus long resolving?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, I am resolv'd no other shall ever have her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: And you resolve for her too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, she cannot in Honour ingage to any, while I pretend.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Art thou turn'd fool, to think thus? be more serious, or thou wilt be dispis'd.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why do you not allow me some relief then? to live a whole month honest, will put my blood into a flame; I have tempted all I meet, and all within these Walls prove honest.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
By your own Experience then, you will find that Courts are Nurseries of virtue, and are
onely scandaliz'd by such vilde persons, as would have the clearest innocence aspers'd, that their own guilts might be no wonder;â€”you find few virtuous persons, amongst Centurers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That's true, but take heed Lonzartes, you do not lead me into snares that will destroy me, for I already find some inclinations towards Pandora, which I am asham'd to own, least I be laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You have reason, for there can none of us believe thee.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You have made me a fine Gentleman in a few dayes;â€”if Pandora be of your mind, adiew to your Philosophical love.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I hope thou art too fast to free thy self.â€”
sp.l: Thou playest with flames which undiscover'd burn,
Vntill they do thy heart to Ashes turn.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Did ever man betray himself as I have done? by putting setters on in jest, which already are become so fixt, I cannot shake 'um off; but must humbly beg to be allow'd to worship that Divine Nature I so much dispis'd in virtuous women, and must now confess:â€”
sp.l: If I do neither Faith, nor Favour find,
The god of Love is Iust, though he be blind.

div.stage:
Not â€¢ , that all the Play through, when Silvander and Lindami â€¢ a
ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If your Highness do consider Lonzartes's Worth, and his great Birth, as it deserves; whose Ancestor was not many Ages â€¢ ince, by yours put by this Dukedom, on a nice point. (as I have heard;) so that to me Lonzartes's love, looks like a Divine direction, to his Restauration.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I am of Pandora's mind for single life, and have as sm â€¢ ll a value for that idle passion you call love, as she.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Highness may as well judge what they do in China, as guess at our Felicities that love?â€”I can kiss the ground that my Silvander trea â€¢ s on, with more re â€¢ sh, then all other joyes can bring me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You have high fancies that lead you on to hopes, which you may never find.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: These hopes are more delightfull then an Age of dull life without them; if your Highness did converse as much with me, as with Pandora, I should convert you.

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Why do you not then change her severity against men?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I had not the Honour to be known to her, before her heart was set another way; but yet l'le try what I can do.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I wish Silvander may answer your expectation Lindamira; but if such honour, and such bliss accompany your loves, why thus long carried on ith' dark? and why not yet avow'd?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Tis now avow'd unto the Duke, though I took time to know my Gallant, before I did admit his love, and on long tryal found his silent looks, did speak more truth, then such loud noyses, as most passions make

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You praise Silvander as if you meant to sell him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: He is no Prince Madam, and is therefore safe from you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: The less safe, if I so pleas'd;â€”do you believe his virtue, and his love so great, that I could not win him from you for a Friend of mine?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I do, and shall not think him a loss, who can be won from me, by the greatest Princess of the World?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: If I could once see such a man, I might change my opinion.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p:
Why don't you try
â€¢ onzartes?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: He is too much concern'd to be play'd with;â€”you dare not venture your fine man then?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I dare, and do desire it withall my heart, and do voluntarily ingage, not to work against your Highness.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: And I am resolv'd to try his faith to you, it may cure Lonzartes to see himself neglected, when anothers chosen, though but in jest, for I can pitty, though I do not love him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And tis my desire to have Silvanders faithfull love, made Eminent by this temptation.

div.stage: Enter Lonzartes, and Silvander to them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
In what humour le â€¢ t you Clearcus
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
Lords?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: In such as does become his greatnesse Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Most brave men are often puffed up with vain glory, that does Eclipse those virtues, which themselves do over-value.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Highness is severe to men, but all are not so vain.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Most are, when we do value them too much;â€”yet I confess I am well pleased, when I find men worthy my Esteem.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How does that appear? when your Highness does dispise mankind by your resolves against them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: To shew how much you are mistaken; unpin this Jewel;â€”wear this Silvander for my sake; I'le own it to the World, that I do value men of Worth.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Madam, I understand not what this kind of favour meanes; I hope your Highness does not chuse me for mirth.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Do you Silvander raise mirth from my Favour?â€”come with me Lindamira;â€” I do command you to stand near us within hearing;â€”I will not run the hazzard of any Censure, by this tryal to satisfie my curiosity concerning lovers, such high Romantick lovers, who soar above the re â€¢ ch of all temptations.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I shall obey you Madam, though I desire it not.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Can you guess Lonzartes, what this tends to?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis a Riddle far beyond my understanding.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Wake, wake Silvander, the Sun shines bright upon thee; Theodocia dotes on thy virtues, and will advance thy youth, much faster then thy own wishes can propose.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: How Lindamira, have you so mean thoughts of me?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: So high thoughts, why may not the Princess neglect the Corinthian for you? such things have been in story.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You speak, as if you wish'd it.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Can I wish you well, and not appla â€¢ d it?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You cannot fancy me a greater curse, unless your own heart be turn'd against me.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The Princess desires your Company in the next Room; I can stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
I have so much to think on, that I know not what to say;â€”the Princess unexpected
favours, with Lindamira's no concern, begets such wonder, as does amaze meâ€”I will not go;â€” and yet I must, or make my self Ridiculous, by judging what I cannot guess at.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Have I thus long ador'd the Princess? and still approach'd her with the same trembling, I draw near the Altar, for this scorn at last,â€” before my face, to court a man, she knows ingaged unto another, a man of so much lower quality then I; this I confess does make my Faith stagger; â€”Silvander was as much surpriz'd as I,â€” Lindamira too was out of Tune;â€”If Theodocia can go less, this change will be more my admiration, then her virtue was.

div.stage: Enter Lindamira, passing in as by him.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: Now Madam, whither so fast?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: To see which way the wind blows;â€” pray my Lord, where is your heart now?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: In th â€¢ Princess lodgings, with yours;â€” or can you tell me better, where your own is?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I change my mind so often, that I know not where I left my heart last.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Are you no more concerned? Suppose Silvander change his opinion? Princess have mighty power to overcome mens hearts.

sp.speaker: L â€¢ n.
sp.p:
Why then his opinion will be chang'd?â€” I cannot value him, that leaves to value me;â€”
methinks my Lord, the Princess favour to Silvander, should abate your passion for her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My desi â€¢ es go no higher, then to look, and wonder at her perfections! my Esteem cannot be call'd love, beyond what Duty, and Obedience does allow;â€”but how does Silvander receive this great Honour?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: They are now in private; you may judge by his exalted looks when you see him next;â€” I am glad your Lordship is no more concern'd.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This is a forc'd discourse Lindamira, pray do not mock me, who have a true value of your worth.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The truth is, the Princess often angred at my confidence in Silvanders love; onely now tryes if she can shake his faith, by higher propositions; â€”and my hope is, that his virtue may beget in her, some better thoughts for men, which will do your business, and confirm mine, for Silvander is above temptation; and I think Lonzartes does deserve what he desires.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You oblige me to say, your confidence does merrit the greatest faith from man; but is Silvander of your Plot?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No, 'twould then be none, nor I no tryall have of his sincerity.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: These are dangerous sports, and we too late may find them so;â€”the Princess and you are both too bold, and do too much rely on your own beauties.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If Silvander can be won, I can smile at such a loss.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
'Tis ca â€¢â€¢ e to say so, when you fear it not;
but I have seen stout hearts fall to pieces by such a blow;â€”you have setled my heart again, and I advise you from these dangerous sports, lea â€¢
they blow up your joyes, when you are mo â€¢â€¢
secure; we know our present minds, but canno â€¢
fore-see what we shall like to morrow:â€”
sp.l: Our Nature with such frailty is indow'd,
'Tis well if present moments be allow'd

div.stage: Enter Theo â€¢ ocia, and Silvander, two Ladies at a distance; Lindamira is seen near o â€¢ serving them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
Is your heart my Lord so fixt on Lindamira, that no Person, nor any Argument, can ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
preva â€¢â€¢ with you to change?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Our Souls Mad â€¢ m, are so united, that hope death can onely ma â€¢ e that separation.

sp.speaker: The
sp.p:
Can no Fortune, nor any Q â€¢ ality ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
you to Honours, and Happiness, beyond what you can ever hope from
â€¢ indamira? Nor a greate beauty dis-ingage your heart from her?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
None can ever move me to a thought ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
change Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
What if she have chosen higher, and give â€¢
way for your preferment also

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
I can smile at all this, when your Highnes â€¢
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ mer â€¢ y;â€”
â€¢ indamira and I Madam, do understand a happiness, can never be dissolv'd; we are above temptation.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Suppose my Father be her choice, will you pretend to love, and hinder her advancement, by your claim?â€”Suppose my Dear Cousin Pandora, have like affection unto you; and puts on this severity to others, in design onely to gaine you? will you let such a beauty, of so high virtue and extraction dye for you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Your Highness sure does fancy what is impossible? â€”but if all this were so, I could dye in gratitude to serve Pandora, but do prefer Lindamira's love, and virtue, above the brightest beauty, or greatest Empire this World has.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Can there be such worth in men? how have I been mis-informed?â€”Princes who do not converse, know not the World they Aside. live in, but take all on trust from others;â€”You believe that I am now in jest Silvander, and do not deal so freely, as I expect.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: By all thatsâ€”I am fixt, past a â€¢ ering;â€”if your Highness knew the joyes, which do accompany united hearts, you would sooner undertake to pull down Sta â€¢ s from Heaven, then hope a separation, where true love Triumphs.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
I am fully satisfyed, that
â€¢ indamira has what she deserves, a worthy Lover;â€”appear now
â€¢ indamira, and call in Lonzartes with the rest:â€”I am converted.

div.stage: Enter Lindamira with Lonzartes and Ladies

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
Here Madam, you are co â€¢ pled by the gods, Silvander does deserve your confidence;â€”
Now wear that Jewel, I before gave you in jest Sir, as a mark of my Favour, for your approv'd virtue.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Has your Highness any better thoughts for Marriage, then you had?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I have found an honest worthy man, beyond my Expectation;â€”Lonzartes you look sad.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My heart is not so full of feathers as it was, but is of late become a lump of lead.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: We have indeed been all too serious of late; come Lindamira, let us find some Entertainment to refresh us on the ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ this Evening; Lonzartes, you, and Clearcus may go with usâ–ª if you please?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Your Highness does honour us;â€”what these various fancies tend to, is above my understanding; â€”As Nature has fram'd Women of a more refined matter, then us men, so she has given to some, Souls so much above ours Excellent, that their Intrincique purity, dazles our Judgements more then their brightest beauty does our eyes;â€”Theodocia is cetainly without blemish;â€” yet may have some notion of my love, which she thinks not fit to cherish, because she likes not me:â€”And yet may have a virtuous concern for my birth, and sufferings, such as her good Nature is unwilling to destroy;â€”'Tis Theodocia's Excellencies makes me thus humbly seek my Right, as her Gift; Else my Sword should make my way to ascend this Throne, which is my own;â€”but no more of that yet:â€”
sp.l: â€”For if I can be rightly understood,
My love may save the expence of so much blood.

div.head: FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: Pandora with Lindamira are seen sitting on a Couch; Enter Clearcus to them, they rise.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: MAdam Tis a felicity to love you, though neglected; by what Name then shall I call my Joy? Now you allow my Love, to what height raise my thoughts?â€”Shall I dare to enter upon such a state of bliss?â€”To be thus snatch'd into so much â€¢ ight, from the long Chaos I have liv'd in, may prove more ruinous to me, then that Hell I came from.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My Lord, you speak a new Language I understand not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas Madam, I have this night seen Visions, and do â€¢ ind my passion, growing much above my own command;â€”For when I look on your eyes, I forget that there are god â€¢ , and shall do such Idolatry to you, as will provoke them, to make me more miserable, then you can wish me happy;â€”But when I consider how vast a Chasme. your resolves have made between us; I sink into such an abyss of misery, that I can ne're get out of.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I understand you less, and less;â€”The more you say, the more you do confound my Judgement.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: All this Madam, is onely to let us see how he could talk; if any Women were worthy of his real love;â€”pray my Lord proceed,â€”I shall take Notes and Edifie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Your mirth Madam, is now out of season, when every word I utter flowes from my wounded heart.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Why do you not speak to me then? who can change my mind as often as your self? I was made for you; this Lady is impregnable.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I yield Lindamira, let not your wit destroy a man that does submit to mercy; I beg quarter.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh! do you so?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: 'Tis enough Lindamira, that he does confesse himself ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ come, let it be Registred amongst our Vict â€¢â€¢ ies;â€”And now my Lord, what is your next desire?

sp.speaker: â€¢ le.
sp.p:
My next Madam, I have scarce begun with this, you d â€¢
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ all I say for mirth; Does not my looks and Language shew an Alteration?â€” All ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ , that did possess my idle head are vanished, and I become a serious man:â€” Your ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ is already wrought, and I now see the onely way to my ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , is to gain what I so much ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ .

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Ex â€¢ ellently well Acted, this might cozen twenty that did not know him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You shall do well my Lord to persue this new path, untill you do obtain a general opinion of your virtue; But I hope you would not have us
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ it at ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
â€¢ ight.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Though my love cannot yet gain credit in your Esteem, do not deny me the joy to think that you see how much I love, and honour you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: This is too serious for our Comedy my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cle.
