sp.p: Nothing can be too serious Madam, to expresse my love, by which the gods are pleas'd to bring me to them; thus by forbidding what might intice me to slight Paradice, by having had you here:â€”'Tis fit then that I submit, and raise a joy from what I am now too apt to repine at, for 'tis a blessi â€¢ g to be so fixt, as Antidates my Elizium here on Earth; this Souls joy will endure like its own nature, unto Eternity.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You are cured then Clearcus, and will unto the Prince confess your conversion, if we call you to it?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Propose away for my acknowledgement, and try.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Let us take time Madam to consider of it, least we loose half the Entertainment by our hast, and so spoile the jest.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Madam, let not this Ladies mirth prevaile with your good nature, to afflict a man, who can live onely by your smiles.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I must confess I have some pain to hold in my smiles thus long, for this serious way of fooling I expected not from you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why Madam, do you take all this for jest still?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yes indeed do I.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: By all the powers above, I do Adore you, next to them I Worship.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
That's no Oath Madam, for he Worship â€¢
none.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have the same thoughts Lindamira, and am safe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
What a Monster am I grown, give me credit Madam, or give me death?â€”If I do not love you, let Iove strike me with suddain Thunder; or I will gladly seal what I have said with my be â€¢
blood, if nothing less will satisfie.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Hold Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh! let him alone, he'l not hurt himself, he onely hopes to fright us.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
My Lord you fright me now, and since you think fit to turn our Commick Scene into a Tragedy; I shall quit my part in it; and from thi â€¢
time, admit no farther visits from you:â€”Let us retire Lindamira, his converse grows dangerous.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This had been my fate, had I ingaged a little farther, and this the fruit of chast, virtuous love; what a folly 'tis, to give our freedoms up, unto the will of Women, so humbly to obey, those we are Created to command:â€”But I am safe yet, and will now play with 'um, at their own game; and through a seeming sorrow for my rejection, laugh at them, who think to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: A good day unto my Friend.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
You speak too late Lonzartes, this is a fatal day, and I am studying how I may make it more
Eminent by death, then by my sufferings.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why what's the matter man? have you visited the Ladies before they are drest, and made 'um froward.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thy love Lonzartes has ruin'd me;â€”yet I thank thee for my conversion, I shall now dye a sober man.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thy looks speak some disaster, tell me the worst, that I may joyn to find a Remedy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: In a word then, I do love Pandora, as she deserves, and did so to the life express my love; that in spight of Lindamiras mirth, she did believe it, and has forbid my farther visits.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis not possible that she can be so fool'd, she forbad thee in jest, come let us go to her now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I'le swear she did forbid me, and in great anger turn'd from me, I dare not go.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This is pretty, would'st thou have me believe thou lovest?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Lonzartes, I am not in humour to be play'd with.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nor I in humour to be fool'd; what would'st thou have me say, when thou talk'st thus to me? thou in love! H â€¢ , ha.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What shall I say? what do, to beget faith in thee?â€”Pandora's resolution against Marriage, which I so much rejoye'd at, is fatally become my scourge, and I must dye, or have her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That's the only way to obtain belief; do but hang thy self, and then a Printed Ballad (The Dary Maids greatest Faith;) will make them swear thou dyedst for love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Do my looks agree with so much jest?
does not my face declare, my heart does love?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: No, nor ever can do to me, would'st thou have me belye my self, that thou mayest laugh at me? these shallow Plots are lost on me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
This is right, had I been fool'd into the Platonick pound; I might have knock'd my head against the walls, and never been believed;â€” Thus I blow away those bubles, those ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
Lectures of chast love, which lead silly morca â€¢â€¢
into slavery;â€”Ha Sanga.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: Your pleasure Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Go presently, and summon all that merry Crew, (who danc'd the other day,) to Sup with me this Night; and bid the Musick come.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: I go Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will retreat while I am safe, and be Arm'd against my Wife, Virtuous, Chast Friends, with their Cob-web Netts, so subtilly laid to catch me;â€”Thus I throw all their Inchantments off;â€”And now like the Grand Seignor, after some great Victory atcheiv'd;â€” I will retire to my Seraglio.

div.stage: Enter the Duke, with Theodocia, Pandora, Lindamira, Teretia, and Irain:â€” and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You tell me a story beyond belief Theodocia, Clearcus playes with you all this while; he love?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: If Pandora be mistaken, he will triumph over Women kind for ever.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I wish it were no worse Sir, tis I who now am to be pittied, who for the common sport, and for his good, have brought an evil on my self, I cannot bear.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why Pandora, he is descended of our own blood, and his Estate proportionable to his Birth? so that if you can raise his virtues above his vices, you'l have no cause to murmur at his love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: True Sir, if I were not ingag'd to a single life, much might be said, to set Clearcu's merrits above mine.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Is there no dispensation for such resolves Madam? when it may be disputed, whether the gods approve them?â€”They give us Lawes enough, we need none of our own making.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My heart will ne're consent to alter my resolves.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: We shall have enough to do then.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: â€¢ et us all agree to laugh him out of it.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You will find little cause for mirth, when you see Clearcus next Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Can so few hours alter a man of his temper, so much?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
He is asham'd of his first Principles, and is angry at that shame; He hates himself for loving, and loves so much, he dares not wish it less; This
mixture of passions, does beget such a confusion of thoughts, that makes him look as if he had se â€¢
on nought but sighes, and tears this twelve Month; and I fear we shall have cause to turn our laughter into sorrow for him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I'le give him Commands that shall divert him;â€”come with me Theodocia.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Tis great pitty so brave a man should be so lost.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Tis so Lindamira, but how can it be help'd? must I become mad, because he is so;â€” 'Twas not a rash word, by chance let fall, but on debate and mature judgement, because I saw none so happy after Marriage as before;â€” Why may not I then live and dye as free as I was born?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You see why, because the gods do not allow so great felicity on Earth, as might keep us from ever wishing to be with them; pray whoever heard of a pair of true Lovers, that desir'd to be in Heaven, if they might stay here till Doomsday? Tis therefore for our good, that such united hearts are so rarely to be found on Earth; take heed Pandora, that you bring not more evils on your head, then you fore see.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I must now bear my Fortune as I may.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
Though you have not met with many happy Marriages, I have heard of some, who all their lives have had a constant spring of love; their passions so high, and joyes so great, each
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ to raise the others happiness above their own; this I believe and hope for;â€”Methinks till I am married, I am a thing laid by, as if forgotten by the gods.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p:
Tis not high passions, nor great joyes, I doubt to find, but their continuance;â€”suppose the Gallant Lovers to the Wars be sent, what
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ will possess their frighted Ladies, till their return? and if miscarry, what will their whole lives have to joy at after?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Those who stay at home, may have equall dangers, these are anticipated dreams of evils, that may never happen; then you conceive not the joy those dangers bring when they are over; this world affords us nothing to relish our delights by, but such accidents as love, with some fears and dangers bring; Tis sharps make sweet the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But if I am satisfied with less joyes, without those pains you find so useful, why must I try to gain more happiness, then I do with for, when I have joyes enough already?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Joyes enough Madam; there is no such thing in Nature, as enough of what we love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I am weary of this idle talk.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And I know no better Entertainment.

div.stage: Enter to them Lonzartes, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: How think you Silvander, is Clearcus what he seems?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lonzartes knows him best Madam.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
I do believe he loves, though I seem not to credit him, and am now resolv'd to play with his passion, as he has done with mine; ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
entertain the Princess rarely, to see how I shal â€¢
anger him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
Is he enough fix't? to be so abus'd, for ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
neither Men, nor Women have any faith in hi â€¢
budding love, he may fly off for ever.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
I am now going to see what humour he ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
in.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I'le wait on you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pray do, and let me know how I must be have my self, that would not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
I can direct you best, if you'l trust you â€¢
self to me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I shall trust you as far as any in this affairsâ–ª let us consult within.

div.stage: Enter Clearcus and Sanga, with Men, and Women dancers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Welcome my dear friends, I will be no more seduc'd by grave Lonzartes fooleries; this night shall re-unite us while we live:â€”Is the Musique come.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Not yet Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I have broke through their Nets, and now the day and night are ours to Revel in; we will be so merry, that our hearts shall seem much lighter then our heeles.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: Lonzartes, and Silvander are without.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: They are come as I could with, I'le entertain 'um as they deserve; they are my kind, chast, virtuous, well-wishing spies;â€”pray retire all Exeunt Dancers. into that Gallery, while I dispatch my Court-Friends: â€”Sanga shut the windows close, then call 'um in, and say, that I am grown sad of late, Exit Sanga. monstrous sad;â€”Now for a grave face to suite with my disguise; I have some fear my sides will burst, with holding in my laughter.

div.stage: He sits in a sad posture.
Enter Sanga with Lonzartes, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: Softly pray;â€”for a strange Melancholy has seiz'd him on the suddain;â€”He is now talking to Pandora.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: She is not here.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: He entertains her Idea in her absence with the same passion, he would her;â€”the only sure way for a lovers happiness;â€”hark.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Blessed Angel, turn not away;â€”these tears must be my daily â€¢ ncence, offer'd at your feet; if you refuse this Tribute from my captiv'd heart; you'l turn the Elizium I enjoy, to Hell: Oh stay! and take my Soul with thee;â€”that gentle look! that:â€”

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why so sad fond lover? let not one repulse dismay so great a Conquerour; thy next charge may prove more prosperous;â€”we come to councel thee Clearcus, and to raise thy drooping Spirits by new hopes.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p:
Or to laugh at my affliction, whose Soul i â€¢
sunke so low by my dispair, that all my Spirits are vanished; I must submit to my Captivity Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That sigh had almost blown me over, yet I am glad to see this, and am now fully satisfied thou art in love, in love Clearcus:â€”let me Imbrace my fellow-Prisoner, we will now shake our shackles, to the same sad tune.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I know you came to mock me;â€”but I must bear it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Oh no! who can have so hard a heart? we pitty you, and have some fears Pandoras heart will break, when we relate your mighty sufferings; â€”but if I should sit thus in the dark, wo â€¢ ld it create the like Angelical Idea in my brain Clearcus?

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p:
This is barbarous, to catch a Lion in your Toyles, and bait him like an Asse;â€”thus to render my passion Rediculous, will beget Pandor â€¢â€¢
scorn, and may prove my destruction.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If she discern not your passion, how can she proportion her favours to your merrit?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Do I deserve this mirth from you, thus to highten my affliction?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Do you not?â€”all that I can do this Twelve month, will not bring me on equal terms
for thy abuses:â€”remember how you held me to the Ladies, and made me your mirth, by which scandal you destroy'd my credit with the Princess, this is my revenge.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
'Twas a great scandal indeed to procure you the Princess leave to love her; by my means you have obtain'd a happiness beyond your hopes, which all your whining Poetry, or your Eternall sighes could ever reach;â€”for which speciall service;â€”prethee good sweet Lonzartes spare ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
Hangs on himâ–ª
me;â€”by our old Friendship I do beg;â€”by thy own virtue, and unparalel'd chast heart, I do conjure thee not to raise a publique mirth out of my souls sorrow, which you have brought me to.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Well then, if I find you do continue thus humbly penitent, and truly thus afflicted, I will shew more mercy then I found from you;â€” come chear up;â€”we will â€¢ igh, and condole together, Embraces Clearcus. and if possible, so order our sad hearts, that both may the same moment break, and infect the world with such a sorrow, as may fright the female Sex from like rigour unto men; so shall we become a Noble Sacrifice to love, for the good of a whole Nation;â€”or if you please, we'l send for some of our old Gang to dance, and drink these Melancholly vapours from our heart â€¢ , to let the Ladies see, their beauties are not so destructive, as we make them believe.

div.stage: Clearcus Imbraces Lonzartes with great joy.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: I marry Lonzartes, now thou talkest like a Phylosopher, now thou prescribest the onely remedy for our disease;â€”Sanga,â€”bid the Musick strike a chearfull Ayre, and then call in those Friends in the next room;â€”Nay, if you allow this way of cure, I shall soon expell loves venome from my heart into my heeles.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What is all this Clearcus, art thou mad still?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
I am wise, and do not mean to quit my cool, pleasant, flowry paths, for your consumin â€¢
flames of restless love, who walke on tops of Steeples, and at that height, plead that your chast desi â€¢ es are pleasing to the gods;â€”But I, who know the end of such fair flathes, as at first appear with such folded Armes, and down cast looks, are but steps to approach the Ladies fingers ends;â€”
sp.l: â€”Then by degrees grown bolder, you aspire,
Till nought but ruine, quench the subtle fire.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What doest thou mean by this misterious language?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
I mean to follow thy advise,â€”to sigh only when I make love to Ladies, (their backs turn'd) I mean to dance, and sing as often as I can, that their neglects may pieice no deeper then their
eyes discern;â€”here Lonzartes, this Girle will cure the bite of a Tarantula, and drive the poyson from thy heart.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Out Hypocrite;â€”is this thy love unto Pandora? was all thy passion counterfeit the other day?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, 'twas fairly growing up to equal thine in all sincerity of Noble thoughts; But the nice Lady would not permit it to take so deep root as yours, before she blasted all my hopes, and in a moment let me see, that love is like a bitter potion, which many tast, and flying away, rather chusing their disease, then so ill a relish'd remedy; This made me return to my old Antidotes Lonzartes; â€”what think you of a heat or two before you go?â€”call in the Musique.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pandora was to blame, to throw him off so rashly.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Let us retyre Silvander, this Ayre is infected.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Go whine fond lover, go whine, I say, go whine, While we chear our hearts with We â€¢ ches and Wine, I say go whine.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I do not wonder that he is fallen off, twas what I feared, when his passion went so high, I saw Pandora was concern'd, but we will bring it on again.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You are mistaken Madam, all he said then was jest, for he is now as mad as ever;â€”I left him Incirculed with six wild men, and as many wanton Girles, prepar'd to dance and Revel all the night.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: There is no harm in dancing my Lord, unless they do catch cold; you judge Clearcus by what is past; but when I see him with Pandora next, I'le give my opinion of his concern.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: By what means may their meeting be procured?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: We'l think on't.

div.stage: Enter Theodocia, and Ladies to them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I am sorry Lonzartes that Pandora has cast off Clearcus, which has occasioned his relapse, when a little patience would have setled him in the way of virtue.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Tis every way what I expected not; his love was as strange as his rejection, and his relapse in the old humour, beyond all the rest;â€”I
know not what to think of him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Let us bring them once more together, and I'le undertake to guess at both their hearts;â€” it may be govern 'um.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I Madam, but how shall they be brought together? when both would rather see a Basaliske, then one another.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You may be mistaken my Lord, who judge by what you see, when tis our business, and our virtue, not to shew our hearts till a full tryal, that men are worthy of them;â€”then you forget that Clearcus conversion, must be by one he cannot conquer.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: But if he will neither conquer, nor be subdued, how can his conversion follow?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If your Highness can contrive an interview, I have a fancy in my head, that may reconcile them, and effect what we all with.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I will send presently for Pandora, and intreat my Father to pretend some business to call Clearcus hit her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: He will suspect.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Let him come, no matter what he suspects.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Do you Lonzartes, once more see what humour he is in.â€”
sp.l: â€”We must endeavour, and not fear to try,
But trust the Event, unto their destiny.

div.stage: Enter Duke with Silvander and Lords.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I ever thought Clearcus did but mock, and laugh at their designs; his brains is not yet ripe for serious love:â€”But how does Theodoci â€¢
look on Lonzartes?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: With much neglect Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
That is not well, have you Silvander instr â€¢ cted Lindamira, that she may inform Theodoci â€¢
of Lonzartes Title to this Dukedom? and how much better then a Forraign Prince, her Marrying him, will be applauded by our people, who are not ignorant of his pretence.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I have Sir, and the Princess gives a serious ear to it, though she yet makes no reply; a little of your Councel and Authority, I believe may incline her to a better value of him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
That shall not be wanting; Lonzartes
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
all that I can wish in a successor;â€”and his love looks so without design, that I will cherish it, and try to win my Daughter to comply.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Your Highness will gain a double interest in all your Subjects hearts by this honour to Lonzartes, who has merrits proportionable to your favour, and his birth, all which his love gives Lustre to.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I see it Silvander, and will recompence his Faith, and his Humility, with my advice to Theodocia, who yet knows not his story.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The Princess must needs hear what every body talks, and all do with.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I shall now inform her fully of Lonzartes Right, too long held from him: bid him meet me at my Daughters Chamber; I will no longer hide my purpose for him:â€”
sp.l: â€”His Birth and Virtue, with his constant love,
Declares he never can unworthy prove.

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: NO, I'le never see her more.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Do you not love at all?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor ever will; methinks love is like a smooth water, that Invites men to Bath, and tumble in it with delight, untill they be destroyed by Serpents, which in the bottom undiscover'd lye.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What means this â€¢ imilie?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This Serpents bite, has Metamorphized you into a whining lover, into the shaddow of a man, of late become a shape without a Soul; why must I busie my head with such Chymers, when I can please my self to my hearts wish, my own way?â€”Prethee sweet suppress'd Prince, do not forsake me thus, for specious shewes of happiness, or vainer hopes of better dayes, thes you will ever find in Court;â€”You are now safe, but when you grow wise, and serious, it will in the Dukes head great jealousies create; and to let him see your virtue, may be dangerous, and your pretence appear worthy of his fear.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
That hazzard is better, then what I now suffer, in the opinion of my best Friends, who
believe this wildness is my Nature, or such as may beget a habit in me, which I can ne're put off; and thus my security in this disguise, may become my ruine;â€”I wish I could perswade you Clearcus to shew forth that virtue, all the World would wonder at.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: To what end I pray? if the good Duke would give me imployment fit for his Kin â€¢ -man, and worthy of my Sword, I could soon be my self: But now I have nothing else to do, and therefore play away my time in folly; and tis a hard question which is best, for we know that too much wisdom does undo more men, then it advances, or else begets eternal slavery to State Affairs, where the wisest ever walk on needles points;â€” I have weighed these things, and do believe 'tis better to maintain the peace, and the security I now live in, unregarded.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: But you will loose the Dukes favour, and become contemptable to the whole Court, if you continue thus Extravagant, what designe can I have, by my desire to see you great and glorious?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Have I not tryed, and been misled? yielded to your wise Maximes, against my own better judgement, and been rejected in the height of my Endeavours, to be (as you call it) great, and glorious, is not this true?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Yes, in part.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will no more of your advice, till you can cure your self.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I have an Honourable Argument for my love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Who has not, untill he be dispis'd?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Was it not your own desire to be negle â€¢â€¢
ed? did you not declare against all women, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
you could conquer? you left Pandora no way ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
victory, but by rejecting you; so that I can co â€¢
clude a good success from what you raise di â€¢
paire.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ha! think you Pandora did reject me, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ compliance with my humour only?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
What else? can she be angry with you, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
loving her too much?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
You do surprize me with a discourse I look â€¢
not for;â€”but I will be no more abus'd;â€” will not see her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How can you be reconcil'd then? shall ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ make love to you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
No, I abhor that thought beyond ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
anger, a woman Wooe, that were preposterous.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Will you treat by Embassadours, and ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
by Proxie?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor so, that's only fit for Princes, who cannot meet to treat.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Will you have her; if she declares ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
would have you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I shall never like her change of mind.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Can you tell whether you would have ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
or not?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That's a harder questionâ–ª then the other.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Will you have her by compulsion?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That were a Tyranny, would make her hate me ever.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: â€¢ hall the Duke by his Prerogative Power, in spight of both your teeth, compel you both to compliance?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Let me think on this a little, at first fight,
â€¢ his looks likely to agree us:â€”if two im
â€¢ ossibilities can make one possible, this might do our business.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Well, what do you resolve?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Nothing, why do you tempt me to farther evils?â€”I know not what to resolve, nor what to say;â€”but will no more of love, my heart
â€¢ hakes at the thought of my last tryal;â€”I blush to think how much less then man I was, and how much more then woman I created her in those few hours I lov'd;â€”

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.p: The Duke calls for Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I'le attend his Highness presently.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I take you for my Friend Lonzartes;â€” do not discourse me into a Ruine, you will share in.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I have no Rule for friendship above my desire to see you happy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I believe it Sir, and beg your pardon for my distracted language;â€”I must attend the Duke to.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You tire me Lindamira, and chide me for a fault I cannot own; I had no other way to free myself.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
You might have check'd his approach â€¢â€¢
â–ª with somewhat less severity, your rigour may be get dispair in him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Dispair of what? my undertaking ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
only on the Dukes command, to afford him ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
visits, which I have done in hope of his conversion.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
You did give o're, before the work ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
perfected.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You speak as if the design to set him ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
were to inslave me to the humour of a ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
man.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
The wildest young men, do often pro â€¢â€¢
the soberest at the last; and the truth is Mada â€¢
we do all desire to see you and
â€¢ learcus conve â€¢â€¢
one another; so to beget that unity of hearts which the World seeks most.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Do you believe that I who have a prejudice against the best of men, can e're esteem the worst?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
If Clearcus were under that notion, should have other thoug â€¢ ts; but when I con â€¢ ide â€¢
such men reclaim'd, do often make good Husbands; I have hopes of him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: If his wildness were his only fault, timeâ–ª and experience might reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
If these be your only Exceptions M â€¢
dam, I wish you would trust me to mannage this affair.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You m â€¢ st not talk me into an Intr â€¢â€¢â€¢
which â€¢ avoid;â€”I do not love him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You will do, when you have him, I know many have done so after Marriage, who did not before.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That is too bold a venture for me, who have no faith in men; and those Examples you mention so rarely to be found, my courage dares not undertake it; pray no more of this.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The Princess desires your company at Court this Evening.
I did intend to wait on her.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I have given you Arguments enough on his behalf, which his dejected looks you see declare; â€”Your favours Theodocia should not be restrain'd, because his adoration is so great, he dares not beg'um; come near Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Lonzarte's Worth is understood beyond the weak Rhetorick of flattering words; he cannot wish to be more valued, then he is by me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nor will I ever Sue for favours beyond these you now afford me Madam;â€”may I confirm my hopes, by understanding what you say my own way?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You may, for since my Father does so much advise for Marriage, I may alter my opinion when I find just cause to value men, above my resolves against them.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: For Heavens sake Madam say no more, my breast cannot contain these spreading joyes you give me, my hopes increase too fast for my dispairing heart, to comprehend these honours you allow, without an Extacy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Theodocia, I shall ne're revoke the freedom I have given, to make your own choice, though I direct you to Lonzartes, to whom ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
Ancestors have done wrong.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
This your indulgence Sir makes me mo â€¢â€¢
cautious how I proceed;â€”Marriage is a conce â€¢â€¢
so great, I dare not at once resolve it, and the same day chuse the man:â€”I can yet only say that I have alter'd my opinion in favour of Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My Amazement, and my concern are too great to answer Madam, my felicity is above the reach of a reply.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Theodocia, I have given you my be â€¢â€¢
councel, and my full consent to please your self.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
I thank you Sir, and will endeavour to Regulate my heart to your advise; and to Lo â€¢
zartes wish;â€”give me but time to examine and approve what I am willing to submit to.

div.stage: Enter Pandora, and Lindamira to them, with Silvander.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How is it Madam, that you quit the field? before your undertaking be perform'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
I have done my part Sir, which was on your command to allow him civil visits, and to entertain the Princess, I complyed with Lindam â€¢â€¢â€¢
to try how our Raleary would work on him, which did produce so unlook'd for an effect, that I was forc'd to quit my part, to save my self.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Were you in danger to be lost then?â€” I did not think Clearcus had prevail'd so far; but if he be reclaim'd, he will be worthy your esteem.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Your Highness did mistake me, I was in no danger to be lost through love, nor at all concern'd; for a man who does declare against all worth in women, where he can get an interest: pray Sir, make me understand what you would have me do?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We would have you marry Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Whether he will or no;â€”If I consent, can you prevail with him?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Do you comply, we'l try what we can do?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I would not be Treypand into a Marriage I am so much averse to, in confidence of his old humour, think my self secure, and be so lost.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You may ventute safely Madam, you see he is so great a Coward, that he only dares persue them that fly him, do but charge and he will run away.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: If I were sure of that, I would seem any thing to be freed from farther trouble.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Trust me Madam, he is now worse then ever.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lonzartes, pray use your interest to bring him to us now.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Do you think Cousin, we have a design to harm you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No, but your Highness disputes me into a condition your self does not approve; pray shew me the way to this felicity, that I may credit what you say, by what you do.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Will you then ingage to marry Clearcus, the same day I marry?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Shall I chuse your man, as you would mine?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Suppose I have already chosen.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I thought your Highness had been of my opinion; But if provided, I give you joy.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Now you run too fast the other way, I am onely towards marriage.

sp.speaker: â€¢ an
sp.p: That journey seldome proves long Madam, when we look towards it.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That was said like a sage Sibell, the quintessence of truth in few words, tis but a willing mind, and then.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Prethee Lindamira help me to be rid of this uncertain man.

sp.speaker: â€¢ in.
sp.p:
I know no better councel, then to be is love with him, or to seem so; for if he should ta â€¢â€¢
you at your word, and marry, that may do you â€¢
work; for I once knew a â€¢ ady, who chose to marry an importunate `utor, that she might be rid â€¢
him, and was so; for soon after marriage they pa â€¢â€¢
ed. and never met more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You are alwares in jest, I would have serious councell now.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
You have had my store twice over to ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
purpose.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: By all my observations, I cannot judge whether Clearcus, or you Pand â€¢ ra, be most extravagant.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
Your Highness may do well to put ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
into the Colledge of half mad Folks, where ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
will either ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ one another, or become qu â€¢â€¢â€¢
mad to â€¢ ether; when their discase is known, fo â€¢â€¢
remedy may be found; â€¢â€¢ is now past judgment what either of them ayle.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
Lindamira saies well, 'tis very strange you â€¢
will not declare so far, as to let us see how we may serve you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Do but leave me to my self, and I am well Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Many sick people are of that opinion, when in most danger, and must therefore by their friends be govern'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
As many healthy people, think themselves sick when they are not, and by seeking remedies for nothing, do create evils, they never can finde
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ for;â€”such high passions as Lindamira's, do never let us rest in peace, but do create perpetual storms.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You argue well Madam, if a dull calme, were the onely happiness appointed us on Earth, then one degree from being asleep, would prove our greatest bliss;â€”sure no age did e're produce two such Icy-hearted Ladies, as the Princess & you.

div.stage: Enter to them Lonzartes and Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Here comes a Homely, and a Jigg hand in hand;â€”now for the second part to the same tune, Of love me, and love me not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Clearcus, it troubles me to see you delight in a retired darkness, or else to walk in such clouds as we cannot see through; I would perswade you to regain Pandora's good opinion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Is the mistery of love to be discuss'd in publique Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
With us, who are so near ali'd unto you both; I think it may, because we all know what you both profess in private, and now des â€¢â€¢ e to
hear, what you will face to face avow; and we intreat you Pandora, first to shew, why you threw off Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You do amaze me Sir, to examine me as â€¢
Criminal!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
You have no cause for this displeasure Pandora, but mis-judge our love and our respects; we know your worth, and would to the World Illustrate that virtue you design to smother by â€¢
â€¢ ingle life; I allow your purpose did become your younger dayes, and did express an Angelicall innocense; but I question whether now, on mature judgement, you may not do better for your self, and us, to reclaim Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
You demand impossibilites from me, for ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
I should change my mind, he will change his ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
Pray shew me a rule to reclaim him by, before you do condemn me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We onely desire you will afford him the same civility, as did first induce him to adore that virtue he dispised before.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have done this.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You did begin, but you gave o're too soon.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: And all her kindness but in jest too Madam, which he discern'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
How do you answer this? Lindamira
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
of your councel.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ him but in jest, and was by him injoyn'd to such seve â€¢â€¢â€¢ as I perform'd, and 'twas then thought the only way to vindicate our Sex, and to work his conversion, which he at first did counterseit so well, as to deceive, and fright me from his farther visits.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Was his love so terrible?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: To me it was, who thought him uncapable of ever having Noble thoughts for any of our sex.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But when you found him growing worthy, why did you not cherish that virtue, as your own Creation.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Because she fear'd her Virgin-vow might be defil'd, by owning such a Man-child of her own begetting; for he began to aske her blessing, till she laugh'd him into so great anger, that one day he proffer'd to kill himself, which gave end unto our Comedy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: If his cure had lain within the reach of Raleary I had gloried in my part, but never shall consent to inslave my self unto the humours of a man, who cannot be a minute in one mind; his imaginations are beyond the Moon, and would have he knows not what.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Clearcus you have heard your charge;â€” Guilty or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Guilty Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: I shall never want your good word Madam;â€” Lindamira tells you true Sir, I am guilty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Of all the crimes, that offended Lady does object; pray Sir pronounce my doom, and put me out of pain.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Will you submit then, and obey it?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: If it can put me out of pain, I will?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I doubt it not;â€”my Sentence is, that you revive that love you shew'd unto Pandora lately.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Oh Sir, the very name of love, puts me into a shaking fit; for Heaven sake, give me Halter â€¢ , Poysons, Daggers, any means to let out life, rather
then renew those torments which I felt that hour I lov'd.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Pray Sir, give me leave, to put him some Interogatories.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Do so.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Lordship has confest, that you have lov'd one hour, and must have some reason why you lov'd no longer; shew us that reason, or for ever hold your peace, and submit to judgement.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: How Clearcus, nonplust by a Judge in Petticoates?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
Why Madam? many of our Sex have pussled the wisest men;â€”give him leave to think a little;â€”but if what I have said, has struck your Lordship dumb, hold up your finger,â€”tis He holds it up enough;â€”He has nothing to say for himself, but submits unto the mercy of the Court;â€”I understand him Sir;â€”and have now found a remedy for both their evils;â€”If you will trust me with your hand my Lord, I will not harm it:â€”and Clearcus gives his hand.
if I have credit enough Madam to be trusted with your hand too, pray lay it without fear on mine, that I may try a charm I have, to conjure out the evil Spirits that possess you both;â€”you may at your own pleasure, take back your hands;â€” only let me hold 'um, while I pronounce my charm within.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Pandora I intreat you to try Lindamira's charm, give her your hand, she deals not with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The Devil I work by Sir, is truth, drest in her rich robe of Innocence;â€”if truth do not convince both these Delinquents, my charm will have no power on them;â€”My Lord you have in this great Assembly, often said, that you could never value any woman you could win;â€”if now you have found this Lady as impregnable as you can wish, she is your fate;â€”hold Sir, remember He proffers to speak you are dumb, till I have done;â€”Now Madam, I must speak serious sence to you, who stand here the expectation, and the wish of all the Court;â€” yet I know you must not consent to give your hand to him, nor in a look, or word comply, with what I say; for if you yield, Clearcus will for sake the Field;â€”I shall therefore onely put your hands together, no marriage, nor no contract make, only desire that you will thus hand in hand retire a while with me in private, to apply my charm, who now do pr â€¢ y, that all the evils which ever did befall the most unh â€¢ ppy lovers, may light on him, or you, that shall their hand remove, before my charm does wor â€¢â€¢ , now come with me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
What the issue of thi â€¢ will be I cannot guess;â€”Now Theo â€¢â€¢â€¢ ia, I must remind you ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
Lonzartes, who da â€¢ es not approach you on ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
own behalf, who is, what you can wish, to make
you happy; and I do again invite you to Crown his unparalell'd humility with a bliss, he presumes not once to mention, least it offend you; I have also a State Argument you understand not Theodocia, your two interests in this Dukedom, thus united, will make it flourish;â€”Lonzartes has been wrong'd.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I know his wrong Sir, and have observ â€¢ d his sufferings, or I had never dallied with his love; I onzarte's clear soul is adorn'd with more glories then this Crown will bring him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If then your hearts agree, give me your hands;â€”here Lonzartes is the best reward I have to incourage modesty and worth, when they do in one heart combine, as now in thine.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Great Sir, I am so much surprized, so overloaden with my joyes, that I have nought but blushes to express my gratitude;â€”nor know how to welcome this unlook'd for honour from the Princess, who dains to raise her humblest Servant from her â€¢ eet, to set me on a Throne, incirculed with more joye â€¢ , then that you now resto â€¢â€¢
me to.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Keep still your Character Lonzartes, as I will mine, high transports in love are not long li â€¢â€¢ d fear.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall be Madam, whatever you direct though this unlooked for happiness, do raise my heart above my own command, for such an excess of joy, is hard to mannage.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
I may now with your Highness Joy!
hope, now your Fannatick love, conforms to the Law of Nations;â€”Now you may talk your pleasure against high passions Madam;â€”and me thinks you Sir, do look as if you lik'd this better then that wise Sect of ayrie lovers, whose Phylosophy doth teach not to desire, what they can never reach.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You are Madam the best Phylosopher I ever met and do deserve to have a Golden Statue in Love â€¢ -Temple set.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: â€¢ ut how have you disposed of your Fantastick couple? 'tis that great work must Crown all your undertakings Lindamira.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That goes on excellently well Sir, I have left them sitting on a Couch, with their hands still fixt, eagerly gazing on each other eyes, as if through them they could discern the inside of each others hearts; by their no motion, and their stedy looks, I can foresee they will be of one mind suddainly.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why could not we see this Experiment?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh Madam, my charm will not work in company; lovers will seemingly dispise, what they like most, onely to deceive observing eyes; I believe they held off thus long, for shame to owne what they had so publickly declar'd against, and to themselves will hardly dare to let their hearts appear these two dayes;â€”they must look themselves into an Argument, for no words can ever reconcile their first Principles.
sp.l: If their hands, do not their hearts discover,
I'le no more pretend to charm a lover.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: May we not peep at the hanging, and stand unseen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Let us not turn this serious work into a jest, unless Lindamira do approve it; none shall stir that way.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I can place you so, as you may see and hear too.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Pray Sir be pleas'd to look on them, our Testimony may be of use.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come then.

sp.speaker: â€¢ in.
sp.p: Your Highness must stand silent, or you'l hinder my Projection.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: We will, we will.

div.stage: They all Re-enter behind the Couch, and stand on each side of the Stage; then is discover'd Pandora, and Clearcus holding hands, and sitting on a Couch, a while silent, looking on each other; then Clearcus pr â€¢ ssers to kisse that hand be holds, she puts him back with her other hand, and turns her â€¢ ace from him,â€” He sighes:â€”

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Turn not away those beautious lights have guided me to Heaven, nor look as if you were in pain to see my heart thus charg'd from a rude Destraction, to an Extasie of bliss; from a desormed Satyr, with a confus'd Chaos of dark thoughts, and blacker actions, by your glorious beauties, and brighter virtues, new form'd into the Figure of a man, Emulating, those Excellencies I admire in you:â€”Oh turn this way, and own what is your own Creation, by your perfections rais'd from what was worse then nothing, to something now, too worthy to be cast away; I should this happy hour believe my self were in in Elizium; didn â€¢ t this fair, soft hand, and those bright eyes
assure me I yet live; from whence some divine instinct teaches my rude nature to adore, what I never understood before.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do not like to be thus long left alone, to be expos'd unto your passion, and the worlds censure; Lindamira has deceiv'd my trust;â€”I now see your plot, and her design descover, but will no longer suffer the abuse.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Be not so cruel unto your self and me, think on the curse hangs over us, if we remove our hands till she return.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: 'Tis too much foolery, to give faith too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
Pan.
sp.p: 'I was rashly done, and I repent;â€”when will this subtle Sorcerress return? my innocense will justifie my blind consent, to which I was misled by my fidelity and trust, and will no longer fear to take away my hand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Oh take nor your hand away untill the holy Charm have rectitied your heart, and therein created so much charity, as in a moment may remove your scorns, and reach you love; for I, who so long slighted your neglects, and fied all civil favours from your Sex, do now tremble at the thought of parting hands, untill our hearts like them, become united.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Do you believe I indamira
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ of such Magick? that her words have power to reconcile dislenting hearts, live ours.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Yes, I find them work on me, and hope
same effect on you, else why sit we here obeying those commands she left? why fear we to offend those powers she did invoke?â€”when you consider this, I hope you dare not stir a finger towards such impiety.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Though Lindamira's virtue be approv'd, I was surprized by her inticing words, and by the Duke compell'd to do, I know not what;â€”and therefore will no longer now obey.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Stay, oh stay, and let the fatal curse strike me alone; my guilts have merrited what e're can fall on me;â€”Do but command me to remove my hand, and I'le obey; that you may see how much your power prevails, above my fear of Lindamira's threats; If so, I may divert your harms; I will against my Nature and my Faith destroy all hopes of future bliss, to pull this ruine on myself, which else may light on you;â€”Say, must it be?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: If I command your hands remove, and her curse should after follow you, my unblemish'd Innocense may suffer more then all your crimes can mer â€¢ t;â€”I have no faith in charmes, nor cause to apprehend her curses can reach me; and yet;â€”
sp.l: â€”My doubts an â€¢ fears, my reason does dismay,
I know not what to do, nor what to say;
The Wonder is so great, I am afra â€¢ d,
Some ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ this Serpent, has an Angel made,
And now indow'd him with ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ Art,
In force of evidence from my stubborn heart.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis worthy your consult, before you do destroy a body and soul; here a ready Sacrifice to set you free, for now I find that Lindamira's charm does higher work.
sp.l: And now again, that dazling light display,
Which did my heart inflame the other day:
â€¢ o gods, I do implore your power to move,
The bright Pandora, to allow my love;
'T will be the same, if now Clearcus dyes,
By Thunder Struck, or by Pandora's eyes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Lindamira's virtue, and her wit, are much more powerful, then her charms;â€”(which I contemn,) but you my Lord, have now by chance thrown out such words, I shake to think on;â€” Your body and your Soul are now at stake you say;â€”and by your looks I read, you think our Fortunes and our Fates, depend on my reply;â€” and so do I;â€”this is then too great a work, for so few minutes to dispatch; we must look up Clearcus, and from above seek ayde:â€”
sp.l: 'Tis piety, when we our hearts submit,
To undergo, what e're the gods think fit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis so, let us hasten to the Temple then, there Celebrate:â€”
sp.l: This happy issue of so strange contest,
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ rought by the gods, must by the gods be blest.

div.stage: He Kisses her hand, three or four times in Joy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Where is this powerful Sibell gone? whose
Sacred Charms do dis-inchant fantastick hearts.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I am here Sir, with witness enough, to hold Pandora to her word.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: Let me adore thy Divine virtue Lindamira? who hath shew'd such skill, to raise dead folks to life; for we were dead in follies, and are now become true converts Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This is great News, you are both well come to your wits again, which does declare Lindamira a great Artist.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: What sayes Pandora for her self?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have both waies done too much, eitherto excuse or justifie my self; silence becomes me Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
Let the clock strike twice, before we credit what they say, or else ma â€¢ e all sure, by I Clear â€¢â€¢â€¢
take thee Pandora, &c.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lindamira is my Orac â€¢ e;â€”give me your hand Pandora, and yours Clearcus
sp.l: May they most wretched live, and cursed dye,
Who shall this knot endeavour to untye.

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: My prayers concur with yours Sir, and now dear Cousin, what I wish'd is come to pass, that you and I might on the same day be Married.
sp.l: Thus for our good, we see the Gods fullfill
What they designe, though much again â€¢ t our will.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Your great Example Madam, is sufficient to lead me from all my own resolves to follow you, and if now Clearcus be reclaim'd, we must own all our happiness to Lindamira's wit, who has conquer'd both, when neither of us could subdue
the other; And now Clearcus I hope will seek occasions to shew the World by his own actions the Noble Stock he is Descended from.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: By your permission Madam, I shall set my heart towards my Prince his, and my Countries Service;â€”I beg imployment Sir, on the next Gallies you send out, least idleness corrupt my busie brain.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Mark that Sir, he is already wavering; Madam take heed how you take the spirit of uncertainty, (in the habit of a man.)

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You speak too late, the uncertain man, is now my certain fare.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Some diversions are necessary Madam, to look on the same objects ever, dulls and tyres the best eyes; but Lindamira can say nothing, I dare contradict.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You shall command in Chief Clearcus, to shew the world the vigour you have too long hid.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Joyes on joyes, light on Clearcus head.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: May those joyes be Multiplied on yours Sir; my Redeemer, and now become my Prince.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We must conclude this happy day Lindamira, by joyning Silvanders hand with yours, if your mirth will give us leave to be so serious?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That is a serious jest Sir, I have long look'd for.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come near Silvander;â€”which of you two is most pleas'd now?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Who spoke ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ ?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: I Sir,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This is a good Omen to a joyfull like may you be both as happy as ever love made any

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: We are happy to our wish Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: He speaks for himself Sir, on hopes of more then he may find.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
We'l Celebrate these weddings sudd â€¢â€¢
ly, and see that Lindamira's praise be in loud Hymenealls sung through all the City, to incourage the like Virtuous, and Noble undertakings.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I thank your Highness for your good opinion, but shall love you for this gift of my Silvander, above all your other favours; Now Silvander
sp.l: Let us dwell Arme in Arme, and dayly show
Our loves increase, that all the World may know
Our hearts: Now the fair Princess does confes â€¢ ,
That Wedlock may afford True Happiness.

div.head: EPELOGUE.
div.l: LADIES, our Author has so great Respect
To Your Fair Sex, he fears some gross Defect
In his best Characters, may prove so short,
Of Your perfec â€¢ ions, he needs pardon for't.
If such sad fate, do now attend his Play,
But you like't, he will on tip-toe go,
That all the World, may the proud Author know.
